stories.title: Free to Choose by Milton Friedman, Series of 10 [YouTube]

stories.text:
Just wondering why does companies frown upon demand 220 in Delaware c corp law (https://delcode.delaware.gov/title8/c001/sc07/)

All of their VC's and LLP have this information handy for them to mark the market on their investments. Why doesn't companies offer this information to other stockholders automatically?

One reason I think is they inflate their perspective value to job candidates which will go bust if it doesn't match with their reality.

An example is I was offered job at Uber and CTO was trying to convince me why they were 400 Billion company when they were last valued at 40 Billion.

But I feel like perspective job candidates are cheated out of this information and this is effect on making rich people even richer.

I am wondering

- If company can opt out of this demand? - Is there anything else company can do here.

btw other thing that happen because of this is when bitcoin last went down private equity firms scopped up lot of Coinbase stock at $1 billion valuation, because they had insider information that Coinbase transaction volumes were actually going up. Ex employees are cheated out of stock gains because of information asymmetry.

I have never done this in practice and but I want to figure is this because this is just accepted wisdom or there is really something holding this back.
